Label: Polar Fast Plasma Analyzer 13.8 second Resolution Parameters - J. Scudder (U of Iowa)

VariableDescription.Name: ELECTRON_DIFFERENTIAL_ENERGY_FLUX
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     PROJECT                         ISTP>International Solar-Terrestrial Physics
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric Science
#     SOURCE_NAME                     POLAR> Polar Plasma Laboratory
#     DESCRIPTOR                      HYD> Fast Plasma Analyzer
#     DATA_TYPE                       H0> High Resolution
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TITLE                           POLAR> HYDRA Instrument
#     TEXT                            Reference: HYDRA is a 3-Dimensional Electron and Ion Hot Plasma Instrument
#                                     for the Polar Spacecraft of the GGS Mission, J. Scudder et al.,
#                                     Space Sci. Rev., 71,459-495, Feb. 1995. http://www-st.physics.uiowa.edu
#                                     This data set contains the differential electron and proton
#                                     omnidirectional fluxes per unit solid angle vs energy,
#                                     at 13.8-second resolution.  Multiply the given value by 4 pi
#                                     to obtain the total omnidirectional differential energy flux.
#                                     There are 29 energy channels from 12.5 ev to 18.3 keV.
#                                     HYDRA is composed of two boxes, each housing 6 detectors.
#                                     A separate stepping power supply is used for each box.
#                                     The values of these steps are designed to be interlaced.
#                                     Therefore, the energies designated in this file are
#                                     interpolated between the values of the two power supplies.
#                                     Stepping modes may also vary the number and range of steps
#                                     during the mission.  To accommodate these changes an
#                                     interpolation is done from the steps for a particular mode
#                                     to the common energy values listed in ENERGY_ELE and ENERGY_ION.
#     MODS                            Generated March 26, 2003.
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0000 TBD
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 po_h0_hyd_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  po_h0_hyd
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      Polar Fast Plasma Analyzer 13.8 second Resolution Parameters
#     PI_NAME                         J. Scudder
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  U of Iowa
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Plasma and Solar Wind
#                                     Particles (space)
#     LOG_FILENAME                    po_h0_hyd_high_resolution
#     H0_VERSION                      0.0
#     TIME_RESOLUTION                 13.8 seconds
#     GENERATION_DATE                 March 26, 2003.
#     LINK_TEXT                       HYDRA Homepage
#     LINK_TITLE                      http://www-st.physics.uiowa.edu/
#     HTTP_LINK                       http://www-st.physics.uiowa.edu/
#     ALT_LOGICAL_SOURCE              Polar_HYDRA_14sec_h0_cdf
#     MISSION_GROUP                   Polar
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. Time, centered
#       NOTES:  -
#  2. Electron Differential Energy Flux
#       NOTES:  Multiply the given value by 4 pi to obtain the total omnidirectional differential energy flux.
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 22:25:27 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#
EPOCH                   ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX ELECTRON_DIFF._ENERGY_FLUX
